column4: How do you write an upstart script that will allow any user to start the service without using sudo?
you can make it executable and add it to /etc/rc.local
I don't have a directory at /etc/rc.local
it's a file where you add your script (including path and made executable) to
And then I'll be able to run `start myservice` ?
and what's the syntax for the rc.local file?
add a line above exit 0 ./mysript.sh , that will be called as root at bootup then
That's not what I need to happen. I need to be able to start or stop an upstart service via command line, and I wrote the .conf file for it.
that would be /etc/init then, but it might be easier to do it directly , like service ssh start (or stop)
which is what I was asking
I have a service (call it foo) which I *can* run `sudo service foo start`, but the end users won't know the user account's password
so just add service foo start in rc.local
The service may crash at some point, and the users will need to be able to start and stop the service.
then visudo is your friend for just that particular service
